header: Jesus Is Tempted by the Devil(A)

verse: Jesus, filled with the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan River. The Spirit led Jesus into the ·desert [wilderness]

where the devil ·tempted [or tested] Jesus for forty days [like Israel’s forty years of testing in the wilderness]. Jesus ate nothing during that time, and when those days were ended, he was very hungry [Ex. 34:28].
The devil said to Jesus, “If you are the Son of God, ·tell [command] this rock to become bread.”
Jesus answered, “It is written in the Scriptures: ‘A person does not live on bread alone [Deut. 8:3].’”
Then the devil took Jesus [up] and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in an instant.

The devil said to Jesus, “I will give you all these kingdoms and all their ·power [authority] and ·glory [splendor]. […because] It has all been ·given [handed over] to me, and I can give it to anyone I wish.
If you worship me, then it will all be yours.”
Jesus answered, “It is written in the Scriptures: ‘You must worship the Lord your God and serve only him [Deut. 6:13; 10:20].’”
Then the devil led Jesus to Jerusalem and put him on ·a high place [the pinnacle] of the Temple. He said to Jesus, “If you are the Son of God, ·jump [throw yourself] down [from here].
[For] It is written in the Scriptures:
It is also written:
Jesus answered, “But it also says in the Scriptures: ‘Do not test the Lord your God [Deut. 6:16].’”
After the devil had ·tempted [tested] Jesus ·in every way [or with all these temptations], he left him to wait until a ·better [opportune] time.
Jesus returned to Galilee ·in the power of [empowered by] the Holy Spirit, and ·stories [news; reports] about him spread all through the ·area [region; countryside].
He began to teach in their synagogues, and everyone ·praised [acclaimed; glorified] him.
Jesus traveled to Nazareth, where he had grown up. On the Sabbath day he went to the synagogue, as he always did, and stood up to read.
The ·book [or scroll] of Isaiah the prophet was given to him. He ·opened [unrolled] the ·book [or scroll] and found the place where this is written:
Jesus ·closed the book [or rolled up the scroll], gave it back to the ·assistant [synagogue attendant], and sat down. ·Everyone [All the eyes] in the synagogue was watching Jesus closely.
He began to say to them, “·While you heard these words just now, they were coming true [Today this Scripture has been fulfilled in your ears]!”
All the people spoke well of Jesus and were amazed at the ·words of grace [or gracious words] he spoke. They asked, “Isn’t this Joseph’s son?”

Jesus said to them, “·I know that [No doubt; Surely] you will ·tell [quote] me ·the old saying [this proverb]: ‘·Doctor [Physician], heal yourself.’ You want to say, ‘We heard about the things you did in Capernaum [a town in Galilee where Jesus lived and ministered]. Do those things here in your own town!’”
Then Jesus said, “·I tell you the truth [Truly/Amen I say to you], a prophet is not ·accepted [welcomed] in his hometown.

But I tell you ·the truth [truly], there were many widows in Israel during the time of Elijah. ·It did not rain [The sky/heavens were shut] in Israel for three and one-half years, and there was ·no food anywhere [a great famine] in the whole country [1 Kin. 17].
But Elijah was sent to none of those widows, only to a widow in Zarephath, a town in Sidon [a Gentile city on the coast north of Israel].

And there were many ·with skin diseases [lepers] living in Israel during the time of the prophet Elisha. But none of them were ·healed [cured; cleansed], only Naaman, ·who was from the country of Syria [the Syrian; 2 Kin. 5].”
When all the people in the synagogue heard these things, they ·became very angry [were furious; were filled with wrath].
They got up, ·forced [drove] Jesus out of town, and took him to the ·edge [brow] of the ·cliff [hill] on which the town was built. They planned to throw him off the ·edge [cliff],
but Jesus ·walked [passed] through the crowd and went on his way.

header: Jesus Forces Out an Evil Spirit(C)

verse: Jesus went to Capernaum [4:23], a city in Galilee, and on the Sabbath day, he taught the people.
They were amazed at his teaching, because ·he spoke with [his words/message had] authority.
In the synagogue a man who had within him an ·evil spirit [unclean spirit; demons were viewed as “unclean” or defiling spirit-beings] shouted in a loud voice,
“Jesus of Nazareth! What do you ·want [have to do] with us? Did you come to destroy us? I know who you are—God’s Holy One!”

Jesus ·commanded [reprimanded; rebuked] the evil spirit, “Be quiet! Come out of the man!” The ·evil spirit [demon] threw the man down to the ground before all the people and then left the man without ·hurting [injuring] him.

[All] The people were amazed and said to each other, “·What does this mean? [or What words these are!] With authority and power he ·commands [gives orders to] ·evil [defiling; unclean; v. 33] spirits, and they come out.”
And so the news about Jesus spread to every place in the whole area.
Jesus left the synagogue and went to the home of Simon [Peter]. Simon’s mother-in-law was sick with a high fever, and they asked Jesus ·to help her [concerning her].

He ·came to her side [or stood over her] and ·commanded the fever to leave [rebuked the fever]. It left her, and immediately she got up and ·began serving them [or waiting on them; presumably meal preparation].
·When [or As] the sun went down, the people brought those who were sick to Jesus. ·Putting [Laying] his hands on each sick person, he healed every one of them.

Demons [also] came out of many people, shouting, “You are the Son of God.” But Jesus ·commanded [reprimanded; rebuked] the demons and would not allow them to speak, because they knew Jesus was the ·Christ [Messiah].
At daybreak, Jesus went to a ·lonely [isolated; deserted] place, but the ·people [crowds] ·looked [were looking] for him. When they ·found [came to] him, they tried to keep him from leaving.
But Jesus said to them, “I must preach [the good news] about God’s kingdom to other towns, too. […because] This is why I was sent.”
Then he kept on preaching in the synagogues of Judea.
